courses.name: Advisory Seminar for Nursing
courses.description: Orientation to the undergraduate nursing program, professional role development, and introduction to the professional milieu. Graded on an S/U basis only.

courses.name: Nursing as a Profession
courses.description: Introduces the structure of nursing knowledge and explores professional nursing role characteristics from historical, ethical, legal, economic, professional, occupational and social perspectives. Examines nursing as subsystem of the health care system.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing.  Restricted to pre-nursing majors with a GPA of 2.8 or higher

courses.name: Nursing as a Profession
courses.description: Introduces the structure of nursing knowledge and explores professional nursing role characteristics from historical, ethical, legal, economic, professional, occupational, and social perspectives. Examines nursing as subsystem of the health care system. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Sophomore standing with undergraduate GPA of 2.8 or higher; honors eligibility required

courses.name: Communication Issues in Nursing
courses.description: In this course students develop their interpersonal communication skills and cultural competency in health care. Topics include social determinants of health, biases in the healthcare setting, diversity issues in health care, health literacy and health disparities. Students will learn evidence-based communication techniques.
courses.prerequisites: Sophomore Standing.  Restricted to pre-nursing majors only

courses.name: Psychosocial and Communication Issues in Nursing - Honors
courses.description: Reviews psychosocial and communication issues.  Focuses on improving interpersonal communication skills and learning how to provide therapeutic interventions to people with selected mental health issues.  An experiential model emphasizes personal skill development strategies.
courses.prerequisites: Sophomore Standing.  Restricted to pre-nursing majors only.   Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Topics in Nursing - Biological, Physical, Mathematical
courses.description: Specialized topics in nursing not available through regularly offered courses. . Sections may be offered either on S/U or A-F basis.

courses.name: Cultural Expeditions in Nursing
courses.description: Directed field experiences in varied settings exploring local customs and cultural/ethnic diversities influencing health care delivery. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Communication and Computer Skills
courses.description: Introduces RN students to MU and MU Sinclair School of Nursing. Provides education in essential competencies needed for success in the RN-BSN Option including writing skills, computer literacy, library and Internet research.

courses.name: Communication and Computer Skills
courses.description: Introduces RN students to MU and MU Sinclair School of Nursing. Provides education in essential competencies needed for success in the RN-BSN Option including writing skills, computer literacy, library and Internet research.

courses.name: Pharmacology for Nursing
courses.description: This course will focus on pharmacological classification and the nurse's role in medication administration and patient education.  Medication issues with special populations will be addressed.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nursing Skills, Technologies, and Simulation
courses.description: Provides laboratory experiences for fundamental to complex nursing skills and procedures. Focuses on application of therapeutic interventions and procedure to provide safe, patient-centered care.

courses.name: Role Transitions
courses.description: Explores returning-to-school issues important to adult learners. Links previous basic nursing courses with baccalaureate courses and begins building new knowledge on prior nursing education.

courses.name: Pathophysiology
courses.description: Focus is on commonly occurring alterations in health across the life span.  Developmental concepts, diagnostics, and treatment modalities are integrated throughout course content. Enrollment requires admission to the clinical nursing major BSN option.
courses.prerequisites: MPP 3202  or equivalent course and PTH_AS 2201 and PTH_AS 2203 or equivalent coursesCorequisites: MICROB 2800 or MICROB 3200

courses.name: Pathophysiology
courses.description: Focus is on commonly occurring alterations in health across the life span.  Developmental concepts, diagnostics, and treatment modalities are integrated throughout course content.  Course is designed for students applying to the accelerated BSN option.

courses.name: Foundations of Nursing: Physical Assessment and the Nursing Process
courses.description: NURSE 3270 provides knowledge and skills in physical assessment and the application of the Nursing Process.  Clinical application of foundational knowledge determines the health status of individuals.
courses.hours: 5Prerequisites or Corequisites: For Clinical BSN, students must have completed NURSE 2000 and NURSE 2100 and be concurrently enrolled in NURSE 3170, NURSE  3200, NURSE 3300; for Clinical BSN Accelerated students must have completed NURSE 3200 or NURSE 3260 and be concurrently enrolled  NURSE 3170 and NURSE 3100 or NURSE 3300

courses.name: Pharmacology and Nursing Implications
courses.description: This course will focus on pharmacological classifications and the nurse's role in medication administration and patient education.  Medication issues with special populations will be addressed.  Graded on a A-F basis only.

courses.name: Individual Study
courses.description: Independent study for qualified students in specific areas of interest in nursing under faculty guidance. Some sections may be graded A-F only or S/U only.

courses.name: Mental Health Nursing
courses.description: Students discover behavioral, social, interpersonal, and neuro-biological aspects of mental health nursing.  Therapeutic use of self in designing and implementing nursing care for clients throughout the life cycle is emphasized. Content on psychopathology is included.

courses.name: Nursing of Adults I
courses.description: Application of the nursing process to deliver care for hospitalized adults with health deviations. Evidence, technologies, professional standards and collaboration are used to enhance patient-centered, safe and effective care.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 3170, NURSE 3270, NURSE 3100 or NURSE 3300, NURSE 3200 or NURSE 3260Corequisites: NURSE 3900

courses.name: Nursing of the Childbearing Family
courses.description: This course provides learning experiences with childbearing families.  Students apply the nursing process to promote health and well-being for the childbearing family.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 3260 or NURSE 3200, and NURSE 3270, NURSE 3100, admission to accelerated BSN option

courses.name: Pediatric Nursing
courses.description: Provides learning experiences with children and their families from newborn to adolescents.  Examines health alterations that interfere with self-care in and for children.

courses.name: Gerontological Nursing Care
courses.description: Emphasis on normal aging processes, health promotion, disease prevention, management of complex health conditions, and evaluation of care for older adults.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 3270Corequisites: NURSE 3300 or NURSE 3100 or equivalent

courses.name: Introduction to Nursing Science
courses.description: Introduces nursing as a science from the perspective of knowledge development. Structures nursing knowledge from a theoretical perspective. Presents nursing research as a method of knowledge development and validation.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 1200 or STAT 1300 or ESC_PS 4170 and Clinical Nursing Major

courses.name: Nursing Ethics and Law
courses.description: This course examines and explores legal and ethical principles and applications as they pertain to clinical nursing practice and healthcare. The information in this course is applied in concurrent and subsequent program courses and provides a foundation for ethical and legal professional nursing practice.

courses.name: Nursing Ethics and Law - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Analyzes clinical nursing situations using ethical principles and decision-making models.  Examines the basic doctrines and principles foundational for providing legally sound nursing practice.

courses.name: Legal Concepts in Nursing
courses.description: This course examines fundamental legal guidelines for professional nursing practice using content gleaned from nursing and medicine. The student will analyze and apply legal principles pertaining to nursing practice. Enrollment requires a prerequisite of a medical ethics, healthcare ethics or a bioethics course which is subject to instructor approval. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nursing of Children
courses.description: Nursing of children with acute and chronic health and developmental deviations.  Self-care and dependent care abilities are emphasized.  Content includes health promotion for infants, children and adolescents.

courses.name: Nursing Issues/Leadership and Management
courses.description: Examines leadership and organizational theories in relation to resource management and effective delivery of nursing to sets of clients. Analyzes societal/political issues and trends related to nursing and contemporary health care.

courses.name: Health Assessment and Pathophysiology
courses.description: Examines biologic basis for selected commonly occurring diseases throughout the life-span. Study and performance of health assessments with application of findings to adults and children.

courses.name: Nursing Leadership and Management
courses.description: Examines leadership, management, and organizational theories in relation to resource management and effective delivery of nursing to sets of clients.  Analyzes societal and political issues and trends related to nursing and contemporary health care. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nursing of Women and Newborns
courses.description: This course examines newborn care, women's reproductive and post reproductive health, and health deviation concerns of women and newborns. This course emphasizes development, implementation, and evaluation of nursing systems for families and their members.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 3170, NURSE 3270, NURSE 3300, NURSE 3200, NURSE 3900, NURSE 3670, and NURSE 3470

courses.name: Women's Health
courses.description: A survey of international and domestic women's health issues; considers historical antecedents and specific effects of socio-cultural variables and economic development on women's health in developing and developed nations.

courses.name: Nursing of Adults II
courses.description: Application of nursing process to care for adults with acute physiological health deviations. Leadership and management principles are integrated in delivering care for sets of clients.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 3470, NURSE 3670, NURSE 3750 or 4470, and NURSE 3760 or NURSE 4270

courses.name: Nursing of Adults II Honors
courses.description: Application of nursing process to care for adults with acute physiological health deviations.  Leadership and management principles are integrated in delivering patient care.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 3470, NURSE 3670, NURSE 3750 or 4470, and NURSE 3760 or NURSE 4270; Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Evidence-Based Nursing Practice
courses.description: Concepts of evidence-based nursing practice are applied to clinical nursing questions, emphasizing use of research findings in practice settings to generate best nursing practices and optimal patient care outcomes.

courses.name: Evidence-Based Nursing Practice - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Concepts of evidence-based nursing practice are applied to clinical nursing questions, emphasizing use of research findings in practice settings to generate best nursing practices and optimal patient care outcomes.

courses.name: Nursing Theory and Research
courses.description: Addresses nursing research as means of acquiring and refining knowledge. Research utilization to impact nursing addressed. Examines development and utilization of nursing theory, primarily Self-Care Deficit Nursing Theory.

courses.name: Nursing Theory and Research - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Addresses nursing research as means of acquiring and refining knowledge. Research utilization to impact nursing addressed. Examines development and utilization of nursing theory, primarily Self-Care Deficit Nursing Theory.

courses.name: Nursing in Communities
courses.description: Examines roles and functions of nurses within community with emphasis on application of community/public health concepts and design and implementation of nursing systems of care for individuals, families, and populations.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 4270 and NURSE 3470; or NURSE 3760 or NURSE 4930

courses.name: Nursing in Communities - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Examines roles and functions of nurses within community with emphasis on application of community/public health concepts and design and implementation of nursing systems of care for individuals, families, and populations.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 4270 and NURSE 3470; or NURSE 3760 or NURSE 4930

courses.name: Special Topics in Nursing
courses.description: Specialized topics in advanced nursing not available through regularly offered courses.

courses.name: Biostatistical Foundations for Health Researchers
courses.description: Examines basic concepts of data management, study design, descriptive and inferential biostatistics using analytic software. Emphasizes statistical literacy and critical thinking for health researchers. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Nursing
courses.description: Guided readings, special study, and/or a practicum in an area of the student's interest or an area which the student needs to strengthen.

courses.name: Leadership and Technology Institute
courses.description: Introduction to knowledge and skills essential to support research and practice doctorates. May be repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to DNP or PhD program

courses.name: Theoretical Basis for Advanced Nursing
courses.description: Analysis, application and evaluation of a variety of nursing and non nursing theories used in advanced nursing practice and research.

courses.name: Advanced Nursing Role Acquisition
courses.description: An overview of the advanced nursing practice role and professional issues.  Provides foundational knowledge on which other advanced nursing courses will build.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the graduate program or faculty consent

courses.name: Trends and Issues in Nursing
courses.description: Issues and trends involving professional nursing practice are examined from socioeconomic, organizational, legal and ethical perspectives. Past, present and future roles and practice of nurses are examined.

courses.name: Advanced Physiology and Pathophysiology
courses.description: Focus on the normal and altered physiological functioning of body systems.  Provides essential knowledge of human health and disease across the lifespan necessary for advanced nursing practice.

courses.name: Advanced Pharmacology and Pharmacotherapeutics
courses.description: Advanced practice nurse drug therapy management for health maintenance and treatment of acute episodic and chronic health problems in various populations over the life span.

courses.name: Advanced Health Assessment and Promotion
courses.description: Expands history and physical assessment techniques across lifespan.  Addresses diagnostic reasoning, differential diagnosis, selection of common diagnostic test, disease risk factors, and health promotion strategies.

courses.name: Research Basis for Advanced Nursing
courses.description: Examines fundamentals of scientific inquiry.  Addresses research design issues.  Focuses on interpreting, critiquing, and synthesizing research findings.

courses.name: Stress Management
courses.description: Review of contemporary research on the causes, prevention, and treatment of stress. Examination of utility and validity of a variety of stress reduction methods. Development of selected self-management skills.

courses.name: Legal Parameters of Nursing
courses.description: This course provides the basic doctrines and principles of the law foundational to legally sound nursing practice. Included among significant topics are tort law, nurse practice act, licensure, effect of contract law.

courses.name: Advanced Health Assessment for Pediatric Nursing Practice
courses.description: Comprehensive assessment of children through adolescence including those with significant health and/or developmental deviations using advanced diagnostic reasoning process. Emphasis on health history, cultural diversity, differentiation, interpretation and documentation of findings.

courses.name: Pediatric Pharmacology for Advanced Nursing Practice
courses.description: Clinical pharmacotherapeutics course that builds on prior pharmacology knowledge. Major focus is pharmacotherapeutics for primary care management of children to age eighteen. Emphasis on clinical critical thinking used to prescribe drugs.

courses.name: Women's Health
courses.description: A survey of international and domestic women's health issues; considers historical antecedents and specific effects of socio-cultural variables and economic development on women's health in developing and developed nations.

courses.name: Physical Function and Older Adults
courses.description: (Same as F_C_MD 7750, ARCHST 7640, HMI 7750, H_D_FS 7750, P_HLTH 7750, and SOC_WK 7752). This course takes an interdisciplinary approach to understanding and improving the physical function and independence of older adults and explores approaches to alleviate disabling conditions that interfere with physical function and quality of life in old age.  Graded A-F only.

courses.name: Psychosocial Function and Older Adults
courses.description: (same as ARCHST 7650,  F_C_MD 7751, HMI 7751, H_D_FS 7751, P_HLTH 7751 and SOC_WK 7751).  This course takes an Interdisciplinary approach to understanding the psychosocial function of older adults and explores approaches to alleviate disabling conditions that interfere with psychosocial function and quality of life in old age.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Preparing Nurse Educators
courses.description: Explores the role of the nurse educator.  Emphasis will be on the development, evaluation, differences and implementation of the nurse educator in the functional roles.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Master Science in Nursing Program or instructor's consent

courses.name: Topics in Advanced Clinical Nursing
courses.description: Specialized topics in advanced clinical nursing not available through regularly offered courses.

courses.name: Research Topics in Nursing and Health
courses.description: Topics courses are intended for special offerings, or as opportunities to experiment with a new course prior to seeking approval for it as a regular course. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Family Dynamics and Intervention
courses.description: (same as H_D_FS 8012). Theories of family function and dysfunction; techniques of assessment; models of family intervention. Practicum with selected families.

courses.name: Intermediate Statistical Methods for Health Researchers
courses.description: Examination of generalized linear models, multiple logistic regression, and multilevel modeling as applied to health sciences research.

courses.name: Interpreting Statistical Evidence in the Health Sciences
courses.description: Students learn to critically evaluate statistical designs and data analysis methods used in health sciences research and scientific evidence for health care decision making. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Problems in Nursing
courses.description: Guided readings, special study and/or a practicum in an area of the student's interest or in an area which the student needs to strengthen. Selected sections of the course may be offered on A-F or S/U basis only.

courses.name: Research in Nursing
courses.description: Original investigation for presentation as thesis or dissertation. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Principles of Epidemiology
courses.description: Explores key concepts of epidemiology and epidemiologic methods for studying the distribution and determinants of health and disease in populations.  Application to public health and population-based practice addressed.

courses.name: Concepts for Specialization in Public Health Nursing
courses.description: Key concepts fundamental to specialization in public health nursing, including core public health functions. Emphasis upon integrating public health science, nursing theory, and methodological/leadership skills.

courses.name: Community-Based Public Health Interventions
courses.description: Assessing and Diagnosing health-related needs of at-risk and vulnerable populations. Evaluating outcome-based research. Clinical practice implementing a public health intervention.

courses.name: Special Health Care Needs of Children
courses.description: Perform developmental, neuro developmental, and psychosocial assessments of chronically ill children.  Collaborate with families, schools; health care, community, family services to meet child's needs.

courses.name: Public Health and Sociocultural Issues
courses.description: Explores concepts of public health with a focus on the advanced practice nurse in population-based/primary care practice; core public health functions will be addressed at three service levels--the aggregate, the family, and the individual.

courses.name: Health Disparities of Rural and Other Underserved Populations
courses.description: In-depth examination of rural and other vulnerable populations and their interactions with the health care system including access, utilization, and outcomes. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Adult and Geriatric Primary Care I
courses.description: Advanced practice nursing clinical diagnosis and management of acute and chronic cardiovascular, respiratory, HEENT, renal, metabolic and musculoskeletal problems in adults, older adults and their families.

courses.name: Adult and Geriatric Primary Care II
courses.description: Advanced practice nursing clinical diagnosis and management of acute and chronic gastrointestinal, endocrine, hematological, neuropsychological problems and bioterrorism and CAM issues in adults, older adults and their families.

courses.name: Newborn Through Adolescence Primary Care
courses.description: Advanced nursing practice of newborn through adolescence of health maintenance/promotion, clinical diagnosis and management of common childhood illness, behavioral, developmental problems.  Advanced knowledge of human growth, development, family dynamics, community resources, collaborative relationships.  Integrated clinical practicum.

courses.name: Participatory Approaches for Health and Health Systems
courses.description: (same as F_C_MD 8425).  Focuses on the use of participatory approaches for the design of health and health-system interventions. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 8100 or F_C_MD 8420 or instructor consent

courses.name: Reproductive and Sexual Health Primary Care
courses.description: Reproductive, sexual issues, adolescence through aging. Design, delivery, evaluation of nursing management of women, reproductive health care of men. Stresses personal health promotion.

courses.name: Primary Health Care Management of Aging I
courses.description: Health promotion, wellness, concepts of normal aging. Design, delivery, evaluation of primary health care management of aging adults from an advanced practice nursing perspective.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 7130, NURSE 7140, NURSE 8400 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Primary Health Care Management of Aging II
courses.description: Continuing emphasis on health promotion, wellness, concepts of aging. Primary health care management of complex health care problems in aging adults from advanced practice nursing perspective.

courses.name: Advanced Diagnostics and Reasoning
courses.description: Expands upon knowledge of advanced assessment , diagnostic, and procedural skills; utilizes current technology in a cost-effective and patient-centered manner.  Clinical increases specialty-specific knowledge.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Diagnostics and Psychopharmacology for Mental Health Nurses
courses.description: Emphasis is on the neurobiologic basis and diagnosis of mental health problems and advanced nursing management of psychiatric conditions using pharmaceutical agents.

courses.name: Brief Individual Psychotherapy for Mental Health Nurses
courses.description: Develops advanced skills in assessment, treatment, and follow-up evaluation of individuals experiencing acute mental health problems. Emphasizes brief psychotherapy based on frameworks from nursing and other disciplines.

courses.name: Group Therapy and Social Skills Training
courses.description: Application of group and behavioral methods in mental health prevention, promotion, maintenance, and restoration.  Designing, implementing, and evaluating mental health promotion groups and social skills training programs.

courses.name: Mental Health Nursing Interventions for Families
courses.description: Application of nursing and family theories in advanced nursing management of families experiencing a variety of problems. Emphasis on designing, implementing, and evaluating advanced nursing interventions for families.

courses.name: Pediatric Mental Health Assessment and Treatment
courses.description: Develops advanced skills in psychiatric assessment and follow-up evaluation of children and adolescents experiencing mental health problems.  Explores diagnosis, treatment, and management of child and adolescent mental health disorders. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Clinical Management of Acute and Critical Care Problems
courses.description: Advanced practice nurse management of selected clinical problems across the lifespan commonly encountered in the acute and/or critical care settings.  Patient safety, technology, and product selection addressed.  Integrated clinical practicum with selected population and setting. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Symptom Management in Acute and Chronic Illness
courses.description: Clinical management of symptoms of acute and chronic illness across the lifespan.  Preparation for teaching patient self-management strategies.  Integrated clinical practicum with selected population and setting.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 7140 and NURSE 7150 or faculty consent

courses.name: Leadership and Management in Healthcare Systems
courses.description: Prepares nurse leaders who facilitate and integrate complex structures and processes in health care systems.  Understanding of partnerships, accountability, continuum-defined health care systems, self-managed teams, and value-based organizations.

courses.name: Management of Patient Care Services
courses.description: Prepares nurses to effectively manage personnel, clinical operations, and quality improvement initiatives.  Emphasizes techniques that facilitate sound nursing management across the care continuum.  Multiple dimensions of managing patient care operations are considered.

courses.name: Health Care Financial Management
courses.description: Prepares nurses to use the techniques that facilitate financial analysis and decision-making for patient care programs across the healthcare continuum.  Focuses on efficient, effective management of resources for delivery of quality healthcare services.

courses.name: Informatics Applications and Innovations in Health Care Systems
courses.description: This course explores informatics from the perspective of health related fields through technology assessment and evaluation, and research and development in technological innovations.  The impact of technology on patient privacy will also be examined.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nursing Leadership, Innovation, and Entrepreneurship
courses.description: This course will provide an overview of leadership theories and strategies for managing individuals, groups, or systems within rapidly changing healthcare environments. Innovative and cutting edge phenomena in healthcare will be explored as well as entrepreneurship. May be repeated for credit. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching Nursing
courses.description: Principles and methods of teaching, evaluation, and curriculum construction in undergraduate nursing education.

courses.name: Teaching Strategies in Nursing
courses.description: Examines principles, issues, techniques, and evaluation methods in teaching nursing.  Focuses on the development of a variety of teaching strategies and evaluation methods for didactic and clinical settings.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 7100 and NURSE 7110 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Organizations & Human Resource Management in Nursing
courses.description: This course will examine various organizational theories, organizational behavior, and the impact of change within organizations. Participants will apply and analyze workforce management principles in regard to employee rights, resources, and responsibilities. May be repeated for credit. Graded on an A-F basis only.

courses.name: Curriculum Development in Nursing
courses.description: Examines theoretical foundations, principles, and issues in curriculum design.  Explores systematic evaluation of curriculum at all levels.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 7100 and NURSE 7110 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Clinical/Scholarly Project
courses.description: Design, implement and evaluate nursing projects derived from theory, including written report with explanation or justification to support the empirical and/or theoretical basis for the project. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Research Practicum in Nursing
courses.description: Selected independent research activities in conjunction with ongoing research programs of faculty. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Translational Evidence-Based Nursing Practice
courses.description: Provides essential skills for utilizing research to support practice change:  assessing practice based problems, analyzing current evidence, proposing practice changes, and developing plans for implementing evidence-based practice concepts.

courses.name: Quality, Safety, and Performance Outcomes
courses.description: Uses information systems to identify and analyze patient safety and other clinical issues and recommend system-wide actions and measurement plans that result in safe, effective, efficient, equitable, patient-centered outcomes.

courses.name: Health Program Design and Management
courses.description: Designing, implementing and evaluating effective health programs.  Addresses leadership and organizational change issues.

courses.name: Nursing and Health Policy
courses.description: Designed to explore and critically evaluate the role of nursing and nurse leaders/scholars in health policy development and the organization and financing of health care in response to the health and social needs of the public.

courses.name: Teaching Nursing Practicum
courses.description: Participation in application of principles and methods of teaching, learning, and evaluation to the education of nursing students. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Distance-Mediated Teaching Nursing Practicum
courses.description: Faculty-guided application of distance mediated teaching, learning, and evaluation methods with graduate &/or undergraduate nursing students. Course graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Leadership in Nursing and Healthcare Systems Practicum
courses.description: Participation in application of principles and methods of leadership, management, and evaluation to facilitate patient care operations in various settings. Graded on an S/U basis only.

courses.name: APN Role Transition Course
courses.description: Focus on refinement of knowledge and skills required for successful transition into an Advanced Practice Nursing career.    Corequisites:  NURSE 8980
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 7100, NURSE 7150, NURSE 7110, and instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Clinical Nursing Practicum
courses.description: Intensive preceptor or faculty-guided clinical experience that synthesizes previous theory and clinical coursework.  Refines knowledge and skills required to transition to an autonomous advanced nursing practice role. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: DNP Clinical Residency
courses.description: Intensive clinical experience.  Prepare experts in advanced nursing practice and leadership to effectively evaluate practice problems, translate evidence into practice, monitor outcomes, and implement innovative models of care.   May be repeated for credit. Some sections may be graded on either an A-F or S/U basis only.

courses.name: DNP Residency Project
courses.description: Final synthesis of DNP coursework culminating in an in-depth practice  change project or case analysis impacting a rural or other undeserved population or critical healthcare system need.   May be repeated for credit. Some sections may be offered on an A-F or S/U graded basis only.

courses.name: Leadership and Transformational Role Institute
courses.description: Synthesis of advanced nursing practice knowledge and leadership skills.  Prepares DNP graduate to implement an advanced nursing practice role that will result in practice and/or policy change at the local, state, or national levels.   May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Research in Nursing and Health
courses.description: Original research leading to dissertation. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: State of the Science
courses.description: The existing body of research literature is the foundation upon which new scientific knowledge is built. This course will guide the student through the purpose and processes of scholarly writing. Students will conduct a systematic review of the scientific literature on a selected focus area in the health sciences. Students will work with course faculty, with input from the student's advisor, to develop and implement strategies to search, evaluate, and synthesize the literature in the selected area. Scholarly writing will be emphasized in this course. Graded on an A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to a doctoral program or permission of instructor

courses.name: Conceptual Structure of Nursing
courses.description: Conceptualization and theoretical analysis of nursing phenomena; critical evaluation of nursing theories.

courses.name: Philosophical and Theoretical Basis for Research
courses.description: Based on an understanding of the philosophy of science, critically appraise and adapt conceptual models and theoretical frameworks for use in research.

courses.name: Philosophy of Science in Nursing
courses.description: Overview of foundational concepts of philosophy-history of science; development and evolution of science and philosophical perspectives of nature of science including logical, empiricism, historicism, post-structuralism as related to nursing science/nursing research.

courses.name: Responsible Conduct of Research in the Health and Social Sciences
courses.description: (same as H_D_FS 9131) This course examines professional research ethics including the rights of human subjects.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Writing Research Proposals
courses.description: (same as H_D_FS 9130) This course teaches the components of writing a research proposal for external funding.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Macro Social Theory
courses.description: (Same as SOC_WK 9400) Building on the foundation laid in Social Work 9100, in depth examination of human development and social environment theories appropriate to scientific examination of social welfare practice with formal organizations, interorgranizational combinations, communities and larger political entities. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Advanced Quantitative Methods
courses.description: (same as H_D_FS 9200).  Study of explanatory and predictive quantitative designs in health-related research, including nested, double-blind, time series, casual models, retrospective cohort; secondary database use will be explored.

courses.name: Qualitative Methods
courses.description: (same as H_D_FS 9420)  Examines the following selected qualitative research approaches appropriate for the study of nursing phenomena and the extension or modification of scientific knowledge so as to be relevant to nursing: case study research methods, verbal qualitative approaches, and nonverbal qualitative approaches. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 7150 and doctoral status (or permission of faculty)

courses.name: Measurement Issues
courses.description: Examines techniques used to estimate the various types reliability and validity of psychological and biological measures of nursing phenomena as well as the appropriate use of existing measures. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Doctoral Seminar: Social Determinants of Health
courses.description: Doctoral seminar on defining, measuring and conducting research on social determinants of health. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Theories and Interventions in Health Behavior Science
courses.description: Focuses on health behavior science theories, linking theories to measurement, and designing health behavior interventions.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.hours: 3Prerequisites or Corequisites: NURSE 9100, NURSE 9120 or faculty consent

courses.name: Technology Evaluation in Health Care Systems Research
courses.description: (same as HMI 9440). Examines technology applications and evaluation methods used to determine outcomes, efficiencies, effectiveness, satisfaction, and cost of using technology.

courses.name: Advances in Health Care Systems
courses.description: Guided in-depth exploration, analysis, and evaluation of selected nursing and other current literature in health care systems.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 9110, doctoral standing or instructor's consent

courses.name: Advances in Health Restoration and Support
courses.description: Guided in-depth exploration, analysis, and evaluation of selected nursing and other current literature in health restoration and support.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 9110, doctoral standing or instructor's consent

courses.name: Advances in Health Promotion and Protection
courses.description: Guided in-depth exploration, analysis, and evaluation of selected nursing and other current literature in health promotion and protection.
courses.prerequisites: NURSE 9110, doctoral standing or instructor's consent

courses.name: Seminar in Nursing
courses.description: Course content varies. May be repeated to a maximum of six hours.

courses.name: Meta-Analysis Research
courses.description: (Same as H_D_FS 9550). Examines quantitative synthesis including research questions, search strategies, coding issues, meta-analysis statistical procedures, and interpretation of findings. Emphasizes conceptual understanding and practical methods.
courses.prerequisites: 6 credit hours of graduate statistics courses, NURSE 9410 or graduate level quantitative methods course

courses.name: Qualitative Systematic Reviews
courses.description: (Same as SOC_WK 9560 and H_ D_FS 9560) Examine and carry out elements of qualitative  systematic reviews: topic/problem identification, data collection, and analysis. Understand how to limit threats to validity and maximize generalizability.

courses.name: Social Welfare Policy Seminar
courses.description: (Same as SOC_WK 9700) Critical examination of comparative models of social policy development.; preparation of a professional social work policy analysis in the student's area of interest/specialization that is suitable for submission to an appropriate referred journal. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Advanced Research Practicum
courses.description: Mentored research experience designed by student, mentor, and program committee based on student's substantive areas of interest and program of research.  Graded on S/U basis only.
